parent.title: Home
parent.content:
Welcome !
If you were not logged in right now, you would see a different message in this here shaded region. Howdy Stranger!
Did you know you can log in to make changes to this site?
Come On In!

This sample site is here to demonstrate the features and layout of your new joshserver. You should feel free to go right ahead and change stuff, or just delete everything and start over, if you want. After all, it's your stuff!

Read on for a quick overview, and see the external documentation for a more in-depth discussion of features.

First Things First (A Disclaimer)
Joshserver is not intended to be an enterprise content management solution. Rather, it's a lightweight and fun interface for developing small websites and applications. It's not guaranteed to be secure. I did my best to make my script bug-free, but by no means is it 'rock-solid.' Please don't run mission-critical applications with joshserver.

Ok! So What Can It Do?
Joshserver provides some quick and easy tools to allow you to do common stuff really fast. The main thing is editing pages. If you haven't yet, try clicking the 'edit' button in the bottom-left corner of your screen. (We're assuming you're still logged in for this step.)

As you can see, all the code for this page is at your fingertips. Try changing something. Now hit 'save.' That was fast, wasn't it?

Now that we've got your attention, it's time to turn to the next page, on headers and footers.

parent.title: Header and Footer
parent.content:
It's All You, from Top to Bottom.

Headers and footers are a common way of including standard (yet dynamic) code at the top and bottom of each page on your site. This is often used to handle site navigation, such as the brown and white tabs above. They're still brown and white, right? (It doesn't matter, it's all up to you.)

Give It a Try!
To see the code for the header, click 'header' in the code drawer (again assuming you're still logged in and in 'edit' mode). If you make a change here, it will affect the whole site. Try changing something, such as the background color in the style tag. Now all of your pages have this background color. Nice!

Do I Have to Use the Header and Footer?
Hell no. You don't have to do anything you don't want to do.

Now check out the information at the bottom of each page. To change that stuff, just make changes to the footer and click 'done.' Easy, right?

Next up: the approval process.

parent.title: Approvals
parent.content:
Someone to Watch Over You.

As you were making changes to this sample site earlier, you might have noticed that after you hit 'done,' the 'approve' and 'discard' buttons light up. If you click 'approve,' then any changes you made to that page instantly become live on the site. If you click 'discard,' the code reverts back to the last approved version. This system creates a nice buffer between you, the coder, and the public. This is handy when you are doing tricky programming, because then it becomes a space in which you can debug your code without the world seeing it until you think it's ready.

The approval system also has another purpose, which is to allow for a typical division of labor in web development: programmers and copyeditors.

To joshserver, there are three types of users: Coders can modify any page they want, but they can't approve them and therefore can have no immediate impact on the site.

Approvers approve (or discard) the content that the coders code, thus having an administrative impact but not a creative one.

People who are both, such as yourself, can act in both roles. This means you're important! Give yourself a pat on the back!
Three Caveats
One important exception is that any of these three authenticated user types can retitle pages. The 'title' is the page name that's at the top of the window (and in the tab). People rarely notice this text when they're looking at a site, but it's a vital piece of information, particularly to search engines. This is the text that searchers will click when they find your site. You can rename pages by clicking the 'title' button.

Another thing that any authenticated user can do is create and delete pages from the site. Ideally that would solely be the job of the coder, but creating an approval process for blank pages seems a little counter-intuitive. Since this is supposed to fun and not rocket science, the decision was made to go with the simplest solution.

Finally, changes to the header and footer are approved when the first page is approved. Creating a separate approval system for them was also deemed confusing.

Onward to site administration!

parent.title: Administrate
parent.content:
Creating, Deleting, and Everything in Between.

Creating new pages is a snap with Joshserver; all you have to do is just navigate to the page you want and click 'create.' For an example, go to /your_new_page/. You should see a screen telling you that there's no page there, with the option to create one. Enter your title, click the button, and you're done! (If you weren't logged in, you'd have seen an error message with the option to contact the site administrator.)

Pages can be re-ordered and formed into sections on the administrate screen. To get there, just click the 'administrate' button below. You can also do a bunch of other stuff on that page, such as invite new users, get rid of old users, and back up your site. There's also a button to delete everything and start over. Be careful with that one, obviously.

parent.title: More
parent.content:
But Wait! There's So Much...

Well, actually, there's not a whole lot more than what you've already seen. It's a pretty simple program, by design! But you should check out the joshserver website where you can
    > download the latest version,
    > read the documentation,
    > get help,
    > leave feedback,
    > request a feature, and
    > see what other people are doing with joshserver.
Good luck, and happy coding!
